questions.text: A 26-year-old man sustains a gunshot wound to the left thigh. Exploration reveals that a 5-cm portion of superficial femoral artery is destroyed. Appropriate management includes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The basic principles of debridement of injured tissue and reestablishment of flow should be observed. Primary end-to-end anastomosis is preferable if this can be accomplished without tension. When 5 cm of artery has been destroyed, it is impossible to perform a tension-free primary anastomosis, and a reversed saphenous vein graft is the repair of choice. Ligation of the artery cannot be done as it will lead to gangrene and limb loss. The use of prosthetic material (Dacron or PTFE) in a potentially infected field is also to be avoided as infection at the suture line often leads to delayed hemorrhage. Harvesting an arterial graft of similar diameter from elsewhere in the body is hazardous and unnecessary when vein is available.

questions.text: False statement about abdominal trauma is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(First investigation is CEC is stable and FAST in unstable patient)

Evaluation of haemodynamically stable blunt abdominal trauma

• FAST has the highest likelihood ratio for the presence of intra-abdominal injury. 

• A CT scan of the abdomen is highly sensitive for the diagnosis of solid organ injury, vascular injury, and pelvic fractures, and is the radiographic study of choice to rule out intra-abdominal injury. It is less effective in the diagnosis of diaphragmatic or bowel injuries. 

•	The presence of free intraperitoneal fluid on an abdominal CT scan, without evidence of a solid organ injury, raises concern of a hollow organ injury. In this group of patients, diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) may be useful.

•	DPL involves making a small midline incision below the umbilicus and using a needle and small catheter to aspirate intraperitoneal fluid to assess for blood or bile. 

•	If the aspirate (DPA) is found to contain 10 mL of gross blood or bile, an exploratory laparotomy is indicated.

questions.text: A 24 year old male was brought to emergency with RTA. He is conscious and oriented. He is complaining of breathlessness and pain in left upper abdomen. There is decreased breath sound in left side of chest. X ray image is given below. Which of the following procedure is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a case of traumatic diaphragmatic hernia where ICD insertion in contraindicated

The finding of an airfluid level in the left lower chest with a nasogastric tube entering it after blunt trauma to the abdomen is diagnostic of diaphragmatic rupture with gastric herniation into the chest. This lesion needs to be fixed immediately. With continuing negative pressure in the chest, each breath sucks more of the abdominal contents into the chest and increases the likelihood of vascular compromise of the herniated viscera. While the diaphragm is easily fixed from the left chest, this injury should be approached from the abdomen. The possibility of injury below the diaphragm after sufficient blunt injury to rupture the diaphragm mandates examination of the intraabdominal solid and hollow viscera; adequate exposure of the diaphragm to allow secure repair is possible from this approach.

questions.text: Abdominal compartment syndrome is characterized by all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    Abdominal compartment syndrome occurs in patients in profound shock, in patients requiring large amounts of resuscitation fluids and blood, and with major visceral or vascular abdominal injuries.

•    Abdominal compartment syndrome is characterized by a sudden increase in intra-abdominal pressure, 
increased peak inspiratory pressure, decreased urinary output, hypoxia, hypercapnia, and hypotension secondary to decreased venous return to the heart. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring bladder pressure, which ultimately represents intra-abdominal pressure. Treatment includes rapid decompression of the elevated intra-abdominal pressure by opening the abdominal wound and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall by Laparostomy. 

World Society of the Abdominal Compartment Syndrome recommendations :

•    Intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) is approximately 5-7 mm Hg in critically ill adults.

•    Intra-abdominal hypertension is defined by a sustained or repeated pathological elevation in IAP of ≥12 mm Hg.

•    ACS is defined as a sustained IAP >20 mm Hg associated with organ dysfunction/failure.

•    IAH is graded as follows: Grade I: IAP 12-15 mm Hg;  Grade II: IAP 16-20 mm Hg; Grade III: IAP 21-25 mm Hg; Grade IV: IAP >25 mm Hg.

questions.text: A young 24 years old male met with a RTA following with his motor bike handle impacted over the abdomen following which he was taken to emergency where a CT revealed duodenal hematoma obstructing the entire lumen, what is the next step in management ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The approach to management of duodenal injuries depends on the location of the injury and the amount of tissue destruction. Hematomas of the duodenal wall will often resolve without intervention and are an issue only if they cause a gastric outlet obstruction. Treatment of obstructing hematomas consists of gastric decompression, initiation of total parenteral nutrition, and reevaluation of gastric emptying with a contrast study after 5 to 7 days. If the duodenal obstruction persists after approximately 14 days, operative exploration is warranted to evacuate hematoma, evaluate for perforation, stricture, or associated pancreatic injury. Hematomas will frequently decompress spontaneously during mobilization of the duodenum and the intestinal wall should then be evaluated for injury. Duodenal hematomas identified incidentally during laparotomy should not be intentionally opened unless there is a concern for full-thickness injury.

questions.text: In patient was brought to emergency with head injury due to head on collision of his vehicle. His BP is 90/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 124/ min, GCS -11, both pupils reactive and equal in size, Chest examination revealed bruise over “left lower chest”, with bony crepitus, however there is no mediastinal shift and air entry in normal on both sides. What is the most likely cause of hypotension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Head injury causes increased ICT leading to hypertension and bradycardia (Cushing’s reflex to increase cerebral perfusion pressure). 

Hypotension and tachycardia is suggestive of intrathoracic or intraabdominal bleed. Because B/L air entry is normal and there is no mediastinal shift, diagnosis of hemothorax is unlikely. Most probable cause in this case in rupture spleen with hemoperitoneum. Left lower rib fracture and bruise is also suggestive of rupture spleen.

questions.text: A 40 yr old 100 kg man is involved in a house fire with 45% burn (of total TBSA). He comes to the emergency 2 hrs since his injury. He has not received any resuscitation, after inserting 2 IV lines, according to parkland formula, the rate of initial I.V. fluid should be.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1500 ml/ hr.

•	According to Parkland formula, IV fluid is calculated by the formula 4ml/ kg/ % of TBSA for the first 24 Hrs. with half given in first 8 hrs and rest given in next 6 hrs. 

•	This formula predicts that this man will require 18000 ml of Isotonic fluid in first 24 hrs (4 × 100 × 45). 

•	One half should be given in first 8 hrs after injury. 

•	After a lapse of 2 hrs, 9000 ml fluid is required for next 6 hrs. 

•	Thus the initial rate should be 1500 ml/ Hr.

questions.text: According to Jackson burn model, non salvageable zone in burn is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Zones of Burn (Jacksons level)

The area of cutaneous injury has been divided into three zones (Jackson’s levels): 
zone of coagulation, zone of stasis, and zone of hyperaemia.

1: zone of coagulation: 

The necrotic area of burn. 

This tissue is irreversibly damaged at the time of injury. 

2: zone of stasis: 

Moderate degree of insult with decreased tissue perfusion. 

Depending on the wound environment, can either survive or go on to coagulative necrosis. 

The zone of stasis is associated with vascular damage and vessel leakage with high level of Throboxoane A2. 

3: Zone of hyperemia: 

Characterized by vasodilatation from inflammation surrounding the burn wound. 

This region contains the clearly viable tissue from which the healing process begins and is generally not at risk for further necrosis.

Lightning is a powerful natural electrostatic discharge produced during a thunderstorm. The electric current passing through the discharge channels is direct with a potential of 1000 million volts or more. 

It can cause death or other signs are acute kidney failure, cardiac arrhythmias eye injury. Internal organs may show oedema and congestion.

questions.text: A patient after sustaining severe chest trauma was brought to emergency where resident observed dyspnoea, bony crepitus over right hemithorax and paradoxical movement. During evaluation RR was 36/ min and SpO2 was 60 mm Hg. X ray picture is given below. Which is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Flail chest 

When 3 or more consecutive ribs are fractured in 2 or more places, a free-floating, unstable segment of chest wall is produced. This is called flail chest. Physical examination reveals paradoxical motion of the flail segment. The chest wall moves inward with inspiration and outward with expiration. Endotracheal intubation and positive pressure mechanical ventilation is treatment of choice. Various operations have been devised for correcting flail chest. These include the application of external fixation devices or the placement of plates or pins for internal fixation. 

Chest x-ray will show 

•	Multiple rib fractures 

•	Underlying lung contusion 

•	Hemopneumothorax 	Indications of intubation are: 

•	Significant other injuries (ISS >50) 

•	Respiratory rate more than 35 per min 

•	Partial pressure oxygen less than 8.0 kPa 

•	Partial pressure carbon dioxide greater than 6.6 kPa 

•	Vital capacity less than 12 ml / kg 

•	Right to left shunt of more than 15%

questions.text: What is the treatment of open pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 An open pneumothorax happens when air builds up in the pleural cavity, due to a hole in the chest wall. It differs from a closed pneumothorax, during which air enters the pleural cavity from the lungs themselves. An open pneumothorax can occur as a result of direct trauma or could be iatrogenic.
An open pneumothorax is treated by applying a three-way dressing to the wound, which involves taping the dressing on only three of the edges. The intent is to prevent the individual from breathing in air through the opening in the chest wall while allowing them to exhale air from their lungs. An inserted chest tube will further assist the individual in breathing. If the dressing is not properly applied, and it allows air into the chest space without allowing it to escape, a tension pneumothorax may develop.

questions.text: Remodelling phase of wound healing is characterised by?
questions.solution:

Early scar (initial phase of final scar)- 

•	Type III: Type I ratio is 1:1:- 

•	Raised hard pink itchy

Final scar –

•	Soft pale flat supple

Increase in fibroblast concentration is a feature of proliferative phase not in remodelling phase

Remodelling Phase (Maturation)

•	6 weeks to 6 months - 1 or 2 year

•	Maturation of collagen, - Crosslinking and realignment of collagen fibre along the line of tension. 

•	Reduces wound vascularity

•	Fibroblast and myofibroblast cause wound contraction

•	Type I collagen replaces Type III

•	Early extracellular matrix- Fibronectic and collagen type III > glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans. Final matrix contain type I collagen

•	Collagen deposition in wound is assessed by hydroxyproline excreted in urine (in proliferative phase)

•	Collagen is Broken down by collagenase and MMP

Procollagen > Collagen fibril > Cross linking > Collagen fibre > Deposition > Degradadation and collagenolysis through collagenase.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is being treated for diabetic coma in the intensive care unit. The patient has been receiving total parenteral feeding for the past three days. Today on morning rounds, the provider notices that he is less responsive than usual and suspects refeeding syndrome. Lab results will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Refeeding syndrome

•	Hypophosphatemia is considered a hallmark of refeeding syndrome (RS) and is used as a surrogate marker.

•	Other electrolyte irregularities may also include but are not limited to decreased amounts of magnesium, potassium, and thiamine.

•	Hypoalbuminemia, hyponatremia, and hypocalcemia are not associated with RS.

•	With rising glucose levels, the body produces a countermeasure of insulin levels, which drives phosphorus and potassium intracellularly, causing a decrease in the amount of available extracellular potassium or hypokalemia.

questions.text: Elective Gastro-jejunostomy is a type of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Class 1 wounds are considered to be clean. They are uninfected, no inflammation is present, and are primarily closed. These wounds do not enter respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts.

Class 2 wounds are considered to be clean-contaminated. Class 2 wounds enter the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts. However, these wounds have entered these tracts under controlled conditions.

Class 3 wounds are considered to be contaminated. These are fresh, open wounds that can result from insult to sterile techniques or leakage from the gastrointestinal tract into the wound. Additionally, incisions made that result in acute or lack of purulent inflammation are considered class 3 wounds. 

Class 4 wounds are considered to be dirty-infected. These wounds typically result from improperly cared for traumatic wounds. Class 4 wounds demonstrate devitalized tissue, and they most commonly result from microorganisms present in perforated viscera or the operative field.

questions.text: Trophic ulcer are caused by all except?

questions.text: A 52 years old male a case of NHL received 1st cycle chemotherapy with CHOP ten days. He presented to causality with c/o muscle twitches, cramps, carpopedal spasm, paresthesia. His initial investigations revealed hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. What is the most likely cause for the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tumour lysis syndrome

•	Spontaneous or treatment-induced cell death leads to a constellation of metabolic abnormalities that together comprise the tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). 

•	Although it can occur as a result of ongoing cell death in a rapidly growing tumor, it occurs most frequently following the administration of cytotoxic chemotherapy to patients with hematologic malignancies, where a large percentage of cells are proliferating and drug sensitive. 

•	Cell death leads to the release of potassium, phosphate, uric acid, and other purine metabolites, overwhelming the kidney’s capacity for clearance with resultant hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia and secondary hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia. Significant increases in serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) occur frequently.

•	Unchecked, TLS can progress to lactic acidosis and acute renal failure. 

•	Treatment includes intravenous fluids, allopurinol, and especially rasburicase (when uric acid >8 mg/dL, contraindicated with G6PD deficiency as can cause hemolysis and methemoglobinemia- i.e. male African/Mediterranean/SE asian ancestry)) and temporary haemodialysis.

•	Urinary alkalnization NOT indicated as it can worsen Ca-Phos nephropathy

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker male presents with pain along the right arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the right lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. The picture is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Superior pulmonary sulcus tumors, also called Pancoast tumors, arise from the apical pleuropulmonary groove located superior to the first rib. When these tumors involve the surrounding structures such as the brachial plexus, cervical paravertebral sympathetic nervous system, and stellate ganglion, they cause a group of signs and symptoms that are collectively called Pancoast syndrome. This is characterized by ipsilateral shoulder and arm pain, paresthesias, paresis and atrophy of the thenar muscles of the hand, and Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis). Pancoast syndrome refers to the collective group of symptoms associated with these tumors, which is secondary to the involvement of brachial plexus and associated chest wall, vertebral, or rib pain. Shoulder or arm pain with associated paresthesias along the medial half of the fourth, fifth fingers and medial side of the hand, arm, and forearm due to C8 through T1 radiculopathy are usually primary symptoms associated. Since they are apically located, pulmonary symptoms of shortness of breath do not develop until later, as the tumor begins to involve more of the lung.

Physical examination findings include ipsilateral facial flushing and sweating due to the involvement of the sympathetic trunk and cervical ganglion. Horner syndrome with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis may also develop with the further extent of the tumor.

•	Distributive shock is characterized by ↓ BP (SBP <90 mm Hg) due to a severe reduction in systemic vascular resistance (SVR), with normal or ↑CO. 

•	Septic shock and anaphylactic shock are two common types of distributive shock. 

•	There is ↓ in venous tone and subsequent pooling of blood in venous capacitance vessels, and loss of intravascular volume into the interstitium due to increased capillary permeability.

questions.text: During a diaper change in a six weeks old child her mother noted a lesion in the umbilicus. The lesion was not noted during a previous office visit when the infant was 10 days old and still had the umbilical cord attached. On examination, there was a soft, red mass at the base of the umbilicus. Although the lesion was slightly moist, no foul discharge or purulent drainage was present. The surrounding skin was not red, warm, or swollen. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Umbilical pyogenic granuloma. 

A solid, red umbilical mass having a soft, velvety appearance without a fistulous tract suggests a granuloma. An umbilical pyogenic granuloma is a common, benign abnormality in neonates. It develops within the first few weeks of life and should not be present at birth. It forms from excess granulation tissue persisting at the base of the umbilicus after cord separation. Umbilical granulomas often appear pedunculated and can secrete a small amount of serous or serosanguineous drainage. Conventional management has been to dry the umbilical stump and carefully cauterize the granuloma with a 75 percent silver nitrate stick.

questions.text: Commonest melanoma seen in elderly people on the face is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Superficial spreading melanoma: Most common type (65-70%). Most common on the trunk in men and women and on the legs in women 

•	Nodular melanoma: About 25% are of this type. It is also found in parts of the body only exposed to the sun. So it is most often found on the chest or back. Nodular melanomas are often very dark brownish black or black in colour. The depth of the lesion appears to correlate with the prognosis of the patient, and nodular melanoma is less often amenable to definitive treatment than is the superficial spreading variety. 

•	Lentigo maligna melanoma: 10% are this type.  Lentigo MM is most common in elderly people and commonest on the face. This type of melanoma grows very slowly. 

•	Acral lentiginous melanoma: This type is most commonly found on the palms and soles or around the big toenail. It can also grow under the nails.

questions.text: What is the grade of frostbite in the Image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(Haemorrhagic blisters)

Frostbite staging: 

•	First degree - numbness, central pallor, surrounding erythema/edema, desquamation, dysesthesia

•	Second degree - skin blistering with surrounding erythema/edema

•	Third degree - tissue loss involving entire thickness of skin, hemorrhagic blisters

•	Fourth degree - tissue loss involving deeper structures, resulting in loss of the affected part

Treatment-

Remove patients from the wind. Remove wet clothing and replace with dry clothing. Avoid vigorous rubbing as this can cause further damage. 

Warm water baths, approximately 40-42 degrees C. 

Warm IV fluids, and this should precede warming of the affected extremity. 

NSAIDS (ibuprofen).

White, cloudy-appearing blisters can be drained but hemorrhagic blisters should be left intact. Prevent infections and dehydration.

Complete rewarming should be achieved before surgical debridement to demarcate viable tissue. 

Patients with full-thickness injuries and evidence of ischemia and no restoration of tissue perfusion after rewarming may be candidates for thrombolytic (tPA) therapy.

questions.text:
A full-term male newborn experiences respiratory distress immediately after birth. A prenatal sonogram had been read as normal. An emergency radiograph is shown below. The patient was intubated and placed on 100% O2. The arterial blood gas revealed pH 7.24; PO2 60 kPa; PCO2 52 kPa. The baby has sternal retractions and a scaphoid abdomen. 

Which of the following statements correctly refers to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This radiograph of a child with a scaphoid abdomen and respiratory disease is characteristic of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. These defects are posterolateral and occur from failure of the embryologic diaphragm to fuse between the eighth and twelfth weeks of intrauterine life. The size of the defect does not correlate with the symptoms. Even a large diaphragmatic hernia can be missed on prenatal sonogram if the abdominal contents have slipped back into the abdomen at the time of the study. Hernias of Morgagni are anteromedial and do not present as emergencies at birth. Any abdominal organ— pancreas, kidney, small and large intestine, stomach, liver, or spleen—can herniate into the chest. The abdominal organ acts as a space-occupying lesion and retards growth of the lung, which results in pulmonary hypoplasia. Respiratory problems at birth stem from primary pulmonary hypertension, the consequence of hypoplasia, rather than from compression of the lung by abdominal contents. Most experts recommend stabilizing the pulmonary hypertensive crisis medically or with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) prior to attempting repair.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding treatment of Graves disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Recurrence of thyrotoxicosis after radio- Iodine treatment is Surgery

•	Most common cause of hyperthyroidism is Graves disase
•	surgery (else Thyrotoxic storm may develop) 
•	Graves is treated by Radio- I (preferably) or Surgery (Where radio-I is contraindicated) 
•	Toxic nodular goitre (Secondary thyrotoxicosis) should be treated by Surgery (Subtotal thyroidectomy).
•	Toxic nodule (Solitary) is treated preferably by surgery (Hemithyroidrctomy)  or Radio Iodine

•	(Surgery is recommended for patients who refuse radioiodine therapy and for whom medication is not appropriate. Subtotal thyroidectomy is performed under general anesthesia. About 5-7 g of thyroid tissue is left behind)
•	Ablation with RAI is the treatment of choice for most patients with Graves disease. A dose of 5 to 10 mCi of 131I is given orally and is 75% effective after 4 to 12 weeks. Persistent thyrotoxicosis after 12 weeks (in 25%) requires retreatment with double the initial dose. After treatment, 70% patients will develop permanent hypothyroidism, which is managed by replacement therapy. There are no other long-term side effects of RAI (i.e., no significantly increased risk of thyroid cancer, leukemia, or teratogenicity). 
•	Thyroidectomy for Graves disease may be indicated in
	Children and adolescents, 
	Pregnant women (late second or early third trimester), 
	Patients unresponsive to or noncompliant with medical therapy, and 
	Patient who refuse RAI or RAI is contraindicated.

questions.text: True statement about papillary cancer is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) represents 75-85% of thyroid carcinomas. 

o	PTC is often multifocal and frequently metastasizes to cervical lymph nodes. 

o	A young age at diagnosis is a favorable prognostic factor, and even involvement of cervical nodes does not affect the prognosis adversely.

o	Total thyroidectomy is appropriate for patients with gross evidence of bilateral disease, multifocal PTC, or a history of neck irradiation or for unilateral tumors larger than 1 to 1.5 cm. 

o	Advantages of total thyroidectomy include the ability to treat extrathyroidal metastases or recurrences with RAI and to use serum thyroglobulin to monitor therapy. 

o	Complications of total thyroidectomy include hypoparathyroidism and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury (1%). 

o	Prophylactic node dissection has no role in papillary cancer but patients with clinically evident lymph node involvement should undergo ipsilateral central or lateral neck dissection at the time of thyroidectomy (Functional neck dissection).

o	Radioablation of metastatic or residual cancer and residual thyroid tissue is performed with 75 to 100 mCi (Mili Curie) of 131I at 4 weeks after total thyroidectomy while the patient is hypothyroid (i.e., TSH 30 µIU/mL on no replacement of T4). Dose ranges from 30 – 200 mCi (30 to 100 mCi in low risk patient and 100-200 mCi in high risk patients).

o	Lifelong long-term suppression of TSH therapy with thyroid hormone replacement decreases recurrences and may improve survival.

choices.text: It is most common type of cancer.
It is common in old males.
Psammoma bodies is most common histological finding.

questions.text: True statement about follicular cancer is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Follicular thyroid carcinoma (10% of thyroid carcinomas) is rare before age 30 years and has a slightly worse prognosis than PTC. Unlike PTC, follicular thyroid cancer has a propensity to spread hematogenously to bone, lung, or liver. Small (<1 cm), unilateral follicular carcinomas with limited invasion of the tumor capsule may be treated with thyroid lobectomy, whereas larger tumors (>1 cm), multicentric tumors, and tumors with more extensive capsular and vascular invasion or distant metastases are treated with total thyroidectomy. Radio-I ablation is indicated after total thyroidectomy, followed by lifelong thyroid hormone suppression.

•	Peak onset ages 40 through 60

•	Females more common than males by 3 to 1 ratio

•	Prognosis directly related to tumor size [less than 1.0 cm good prognosis]

•	Associated Genes are- P53, PTEN, Ras, PAX8/PPAR1

•	Spread to lymph nodes is uncommon (<10%)

•	Invasion into vascular structures within the thyroid gland is common

•	Distant spread to BONES (Osteolytic, pulsatile to flat bones) or lungs more common than with papillary cancer

•	Overall cure rate high (near 95% for small lesions in young patients), decreases with advanced age

•	Follicular adenoma and carcinoma have same uniform pattern. 

•	Usually solitary and well incapsulated. 

•	Detection of papilla/ Orphan Annie nucleus/ Psammoma bodies (Features of papillary cancer) is not consistent with follicular carcinoma.

•	Distinction of carcinoma and adenoma is based on capsular and vascular invasion, thus its differentiation is not possible by FNAC.

•	Good prognostic features are: Small size (< 4cm), persons younger than 50 yrs, localized tumours without marked vascular invasion.

•	Treated by total thyroidectomy (for <1cm hemithyroidectomy suffices).  

•	Bome mets are treated by Radio-I and in non-responders by Radiotherapy

questions.text: A 50 yrs female patient presented with a thyroid nodule in right lobe. FNAC of nodule showed amyloid stroma. Ideal treatment for her would be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

MEDULLARY THYROID CARCINOMA: 5%
•	It can be associated with other endocrine tumors – MEN II A and B
•	F> M. (except for inherited cancers). Commonest in 5th – 6th decades. >50% are bilateral.
•	Regional metastases (spread to neck lymph nodes) occurs early in the disease
•	Spread to distant organs (metastasis) occurs late and can be to the liver, bone, brain, and adrenal medulla
•	Diarrhoea is common 
•	FNAC shows amyloid stroma.
•	Usually originates in the upper central lobe of the thyroid
•	Poor prognostic factors include age >50, male, distant spread (metastases), and when seen in patients with other endocrine tumors due to MEN II-B syndrome.
•	Residual disease (following surgery) or recurrence can be detected by measuring calcitonin (a hormone that should be measured every 4 months for the first few years and then every 6 months for ever).
•	20% of patients acquire this through autosomal dominant inherited pattern.
•	Germ line abnormality of chromosome 10 (pericentrometric region) is related to 3 different familial pattern (MEN II a, MEN II b, and non MEN medullayr carcinoma).
•	MCT associated with MEN are multicentric, in younger age and associated with C cell hyperplasia.
•	MTC is screened by Pantagastin stimulated or calcium stimulated plasma level of calcitonin.
•	Metastasis is through lymphatics and blood vessels (Liver).
•	Though calcitonin is high but hypercalcemia is not a notable feature.  
•	Prognosis is worse in: Older patients, MEN II b, large tumour size, Lymph node mets and distant metastasis.
•	Treatment: Total thyroidectomy with central node dissection. If neck nodes are positive or big tumour than Radical neck dissection should be done.
•	“Prophylactic Total thyroidectomy is indicated in RET positive (MEN syndrome) in childhood. In MEN 2a it is done < 5 years while in MEN 2b it is done < 1 years”. If calcitonin is high than central neck dissection can be added with total thyroidectomy.
•	In setting of Familial MCT patient with basal or stimulated calcitonin relative should undergo a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection
•	It is important to screen for catecholamine excess prior to surgical exploration to rule out familial syndrome with an occult pheochromocytoma.
•	Radio-I has no role in treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primary hyper-parathyroidism causes causes hypophosphatemia. Hyperphosphatemia is seen in secondary hyperthyroidism.

Due the serum calcium level going above the renal threshold of calcium resorption finally patients have hypercaleuria

The parathyroid glands secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH) a polypeptide of 84 amino acids. PTH increases the concentration of Ca2+ in the blood in three ways. 

Release of Ca2+ from the huge reservoir in the bones. (99% of the calcium in the body is incorporated in our bones.) 

Reabsorption of Ca2+ from the fluid in the tubules in the kidneys 

Absorption of Ca2+ from the contents of the intestine (this action is mediated by calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D.) 

PTH also regulates the level of phosphate. PTH reduces the efficiency for phosphate resorption in the proximal tubules causing a drop in the phosphate concentration. 

Control of the Parathyroids: the calcium receptor

The cells of the parathyroid glands have surface G-protein-coupled receptors that bind Ca2+. Binding of Ca2+ to this receptor depresses the secretion of PTH and thus leads to a lowering of the concentration of Ca2+ in the blood.

questions.text: Indication of parathyroidectomy in a case of asymptomatic primary parathyroidism is?

Correct Answer (D)

Criteria for Surgical Referral From the 2002 National Institutes of Health Workshop on Asymptomatic Primary Hyperparathyroidism

•	Serum calcium concentration >1 mg/dL above the upper limits of normal 

•	24-hour urinary calcium >400 mg 

•	Creatinine clearance reduced by >30% in comparison to age-matched subjects 

•	Bone density at the lumbar spine, hip, or distal end of the radius that is >2 standard deviations below peak bone mass (T-score <-2.5) 

•	All individuals with primary hyperparathyroidism and <50 years are referred for surgery 

•	Patients for whom medical surveillance is either undesirable or impossible

questions.text: A mahogany coloured renal tumour with central fibrotic scar, with large cell and granular cytoplasm is probably?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Features are suggestive of Renal oncocytoma which is benign tumour.

Renal oncocytoma (5% of the tumors); is derived from tubular epithelium). While most tumors are incidentally found, they can present as a mass or with hematuria. 

Histologically tumor cells exhibit large and finely granular cytoplasm, uniform round nuclei, clumped chromatin and small nucleoli. 

Conservative surgery is considered an adequate treatment since true oncocytomas are always benign. 
Renal oncocytoma has a characteristic central white fibrous scar. 

Although rare, necrosis may occur and Hemorrhage is common. 

Bilaterally or multicentricity are common.

ADPK

PKD1 and PKD2- polycystin 1 and polycystin 2

(A third candidate gene, GANAB [Glucosidase II Alpha Subunit], has been recently described)
Located on Chromosome 16 & 4

ADPK is characterized by B/L renal cysts, Liver cysts, cysts in pancreas, spleen and ovary. Subarachnoid cysts, 
Berry aneurysm, Mitral valve prolapse syndrome (heart) and diverticulosis (colon).

A rise in diastolic blood pressure is the rule in ADPKD.

The drugs of choice are angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors (eg, captopril, enalapril, lisinopril) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) such as telmisartan, losartan, irbesartan, and candesartan
Tolvaptan, a selective vasopressin V2-receptor antagonist, is approved by FDA April 2018 to slow kidney function decline in adults at risk of rapidly progressing ADPKD. 

Rovsing operation is not done now. Only definitive treatment is renal transplant.

questions.text: Michelis Gutamen bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Malacoplakia (Greek- Soft plaque)

•	Malacoplakia is is characterized by von Hansemann as soft, yellow-brown plaques with granulomatous lesions in which the histiocytes contain distinct basophilic inclusions or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

•	Malacoplakia probably results from abnormal macrophage function in response to a bacterial infection, which is most often E. coli. Common in immunodeficiency syndrome, autoimmune disease, carcinoma, or another systemic disorder

•	There is inadequate killing of bacteria by macrophages due to defective phagolysosomal activity.

•	It is more common in immunosuppressed, DM, Lymphoma and Rheumatoid arthritis.

•	It is hypothesized that bacteria or bacterial fragments form the nidus for the calcium phosphate crystals that laminate the Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. 

•	The diagnosis is made by biopsy. The lesion is characterized by large histiocytes, known as von Hansemann cells, and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

•	Septran and Quinoline are drug of choice

questions.text: False statement about Posterior urethral valve is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior urethral valve

Only seen in males, Type I is most common, Valve is present just below Veru montanum
Presents with obsructive urinary symptom, distended bladder, VUR (in 50%)- gross Hydro-ureteronephrosis, deranged renal function (in 30%) and urinary ascites
Associated features are- Oligohydromnios, Renal dysplasia, Bladder dysfunction, Pulmonary hypoplasia (M/C cause of death)
MCU is IOC. USG shows key hole sign (Prenatal diagnosis can be made on USG after 28 weeks)
Endoscopic fulguration is treatment of choice
In deranged renal function or urinary ascites Vasicostomy is best (Blockson’s technique)

Posterior urethral valve is most common obstructive urethral lesion in male child. It occurs only male child and is present at the distal prostatic urethra. Most common type is type 1 (Below Veru Montanum). Presents with obstructive urinary symptom, distended bladder, severe hydroureteronephrosis, urinary ascites, VUR and renal failure. Associated oligohydroamnios may be found in severe cases.
MCU (Micturating custourethragram or voiding cystourethragram) is the best investigation. 
 USG: Detects large volume bladder with trabaculation, hydroureter and hydronephrosis. It may show dilated posterior urethra and can be used, in-utero, to detect urethral valves (as aerly as 28 weeks).
Cystoscopy: The valves are difficult to see at cystoscopy, because irrigating fluid sweeps them into open position.
Treatment: Cystoscopic fugulration is the treatment of choice. If in a newborn, Bladder is excessively dilated with complete atony and presence of hydrouretronephrosis, first stage diversion may be done by vesicostomy or uretrostomy.
Pulonary hypoplasia is most common cause of death

questions.text: Ideal treatment for staghorn calculus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ideal treatment for < 2cm stone is ESWL or RIRS

For > 2cm stone ideal treatment is PCNL

STRUVITE STONES (STAGHORN CALCULI)

•	Synonyms: infection stones, triple phosphate stones.

•	Women > men, perhaps because of their susceptibility for UT1. 

•	Tend to grow in alkaline urine and tend to fill whole of the PCS. 

•	Composed of magnesium, ammonium & phosphate (MAP) 

•	Pathogenesis: Two conditions must coexist for crystallization of struvite.

	Urine pH of 7.2 or above.

	Ammonia in the urine (produced from hydrolysis of urea by urease producing bacteria).

•	Two urological conditions which contribute to the tendency to form struvite calculi:

	Foreign body in the urinary tract e.g. Foley's catheter.

	Neurogenic bladder

•	Most of the stag horn calculi are silent and cause progressive destruction of renal parenchyma. 

RENAL CALCULI

•	Peak incidence 20-40 years; Males 3 times affected.

•	Infectious stones (UTI common in women).

•	MC Calculi are calcium stones occurring in combination with either oxalates or phosphates. 
4 most common types of stones -

•	Calcium containing stones [calcium oxalate (MC), calcium phosphate, mixed] - 70%. o   Infection stones (struvite) - 15-20% 

•	Uric acid stones - 5 -10% 

•	Cystine stones - 1-5% 

Cal Oxalate stone are called Mulberry stone (Most common)

Model of formation of renal calculi (Super saturation and crystallization). 

PH for crystallization.

Uric acid and cystine calculi - acidic urine (PH < 6) 

 Struvite (MAP) phosphates - alkaline urine

Calcium oxalate can form at any pH

questions.text: Which endocrine abnormality is likely to be associated with in a patient of GIST treated on Imatinib?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Consumption hypothyroidism due to activation of deiodinase and destruction of T3 is a known complication or GIST with hypothyroidism. 
Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)
•	GIST arises from interstitial cell of Cajal (GI pacemaker cells)
•	Most common sites: Stomach (50-60%)> ileum (25%).
•	Most are positive for CD117 (>90%), DOG 1, CD 34 (>70%).
•	Most common presentation- Hematemesis
•	Has a tendency for Blood born secondaries (liver) and direct invasion. 
•	Mostly Node negative
•	Most are CKit positive while some are PDG alpha positive(PDGF α has good prognosis)
•	Two types: Spindle cell (70% most common), epitheloid (30%) and rarely pleomorphic.
•	Malignant potential is decided by Fletcher criteria:
•	1: Size > 5 cm
•	2: Mitotic Index: > 50/ 10 HPF 
•	3: metastasis: Vascular or peritoneal (Lymphatic involvement is very rare- 5%)
•	IOC CT scan
•	For recurrence PET scan
•	For Biopsy- EUS guided biopsy (GIST found in layer 4 >2)) 
•	Treatment of GIST: Surgical resection (segmental with 2 cm margin)
•	Imatinib mesylate (selective inhibitor of type 3 tyrosine kinase KIT) 400mg/day is best adjuvant therapy. Used in CKit positive GIST.
•	Sunitinib is used in Imatinib resistance cases.
•	Mitotic index and Tumour size is predominant factor for survival.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. Subsequent “MRCP” reveals a cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film shown here. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is type I choledochal cyst which is the commonest type (>85%)
Five major types are (Todani):

•	Type I cysts are the most common and represent 80-90% of choledochal cysts. They consist of saccular or fusiform dilatations of the common bile duct, which involve either a segment of the duct or the entire duct. 
•	Type II choledochal cysts appear as an isolated diverticulum protruding from the wall of the common bile duct. 
•	Type III choledochal cysts arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct (choledochocele).

The surgical management for each choledochal cyst type is described as follows:
•	Type I: Complete excision of cyst followed by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
•	Type II: Complete excision of the dilated diverticulum comprising a type II choledochal cyst; the resultant defect in the common bile duct is closed over a T-tube
•	Type III (choledochocele): choledochoceles measuring 3 cm or less can be treated effectively with endoscopic sphincterotomy, whereas lesions larger than 3 cm are excised surgically via a transduodenal approach.
•	Type IV: Complete excision of the dilated extrahepatic duct, followed by a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy to restore continuity.
•	Type V (Caroli disease): Hepatic lobectomy for disease limited to one hepatic lobe (left lobe usually affected); patients with bilobar disease manifesting signs of liver failure, biliary cirrhosis, or portal hypertension may require liver transplantation
•	Lilly technique: When the cyst adheres densely to the portal vein secondary to long-standing inflammatory reaction, it may not be possible to perform a complete, full-thickness excision of the cyst; the Lilly technique allows the serosal surface of the duct to be left adhering to the portal vein, while the mucosa of the cyst wall is obliterated by curettage or cautery—theoretically, this removes the risk of malignant transformation in that segment of the duct

questions.text: What is the treatment of patient with carcinoid tumor of 1.5 cm at the base of appendix attached to caecum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

If Carcinoid tumors are less than 1 cm in size then only appendectomy is sufficient. If Carcinoid tumor is more than 2 cm in size we have to subject the patient to right hemicolectomy.

If Carcinoid tumour is between 1 to 2 cm then we have to consider the following condition:  If it involves base (< 2cm from caecum), if it involves mesoappendix or if the lymph nodes are involved we have to subject the patient to right hemicolectomy. If it does not involve the base, if mesoappendix is not involved and if no lymph node enlargement is present we can do only appendectomy in these patients

questions.text: A 26-years old male presented with 4 day history of pain in the right sided lower abdomen, low grade fever and frequent vomiting. Patients general condition is fair and clinically a tender lump was felt in the right iliac fossa. CT scan showed a lump in right iliac fossa without any free fluid indie the lump. Most appropriate management for this case would be:?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This a clinical case scenario describing appendicular lump so in this we will follow an Ochsner sherren regimen which is basically conservative treatment of appendicular lump, keep patient nil per oral and give antibiotics, and we monitor temperature and pulse rate at serial intervals, if the patient improves we continue this treatment and then call the patient for interval appendectomy after 6 weeks.

questions.text: A neonate presents with colicky pain and vomiting with sausage-shaped lump in the abdomen and red currant jelly stools. What investigation should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intussusception

Peak incidence age -  6 month- 1 year (Weaning)

Frequently occurs infection Adenovirus type 3 virus (lymphoid hyperplasia that act as “lead point” (of Peyer's patch).

• USG -  Target sign, Pseudokidney sign

• Ba enema – Claw sign/ Coiled spring sign

Types

  • Ileocolic – Most common type 70% (in children)
  • Colocolic – Most common type in adults

Clinical features

  • Red Currant Jelly tool
  • Sausage shaped or banana shaped lump
  • Empty right iliac fossa (Sign of dance)

Treatment:

  • Reduction with air or contrast enema (>70% success)
  • Surgical reduction:
  •  Peritonitis, shock or failed reduction requires surgery. ( Gangrene starts from the apex)

questions.text: While doing surgery for a small cyst in mesentery, Surgeon incidentally found the structure shown in the image, in the terminal ileum. Which one of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Meckel’s diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum which consists of all layers from mucosa to serosa

(B) Option B is wrong as meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticum and consists of all the three layers that is mucosa muscle coat and serosa. Option A is correct as meckel’s diverticulum is present always on the antimesenteric border of the intestine. Option C is correct as ectopic gastric mucosa can be present in the meckel’s diverticulum and due to the acid production by the gastric mucosa there can occur ulceration of the mucosa and this can lead to bleeding. Optionn D is correct as sometimes there occurs a fibrous band between the meckels diverticulum and the umbilicus and intestine can roll around this fibrous band and lead to intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A obese old patient with diverticular disease presents with perforation, what is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The patient is presenting in an emergency condition presenting with perforation in diverticulitis. Hartmann’s operation is the most common technique for emergency operations required for control of infection secondary to diverticulitis, In this case we do not perform immediate anastomosis between descending colon and rectum as there is high chance that it will leak and complicate because of excessive inflamed and edematous tissue. Anastomosis between the descending colon and rectum to restore intestinal continuity is done after a period of at least 10 weeks.
